top_categories.workout_context: UCI Gravel Suisse’s 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. starts flat in rhone valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. features a brutal 20% gradient section on route des chaux before the col de la croix finish and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Racing UCI Gravel Suisse isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.

UCI Gravel Suisse’s 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. starts flat in rhone valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. features a brutal 20% gradient section on route des chaux before the col de la croix finish demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at UCI Gravel Suisse when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.

UCI Gravel Suisse’s 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. starts flat in rhone valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. features a brutal 20% gradient section on route des chaux before the col de la croix finish drains energy reserves faster than the distance suggests — durability training bridges the gap.
UCI Gravel Suisse rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
UCI Gravel Suisse’s 11,300ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at UCI Gravel Suisse — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of UCI Gravel Suisse. Make this intensity feel like home.

Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at UCI Gravel Suisse — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. starts flat in rhone valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. features a brutal 20% gradient section on route des chaux before the col de la croix finish.
Every session at UCI Gravel Suisse intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for UCI Gravel Suisse’s 11,300ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.

race_overlay.heat: July in Aigle / Villars-sur-Ollon, Switzerland can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before UCI Gravel Suisse. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for UCI Gravel Suisse’s 68 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.altitude: Moderate altitude at UCI Gravel Suisse. Arrive 2–3 days early. Reduce intensity expectations by 5–10%. Hydrate aggressively.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at UCI Gravel Suisse requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. starts flat in rhone valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. features a brutal 20% gradient section on route des chaux before the col de la croix finish to build confidence.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, Race Simulation, and Gravel Specific to prepare you for 68 miles of 50% paved / 50% unpaved alpine terrain. starts flat in rhone valley, transitions to steep forest climbs and high-altitude gravel roads. features a brutal 20% gradient section on route des chaux before the col de la croix finish in Aigle / Villars-sur-Ollon, Switzerland.
